thread.title: National Writer: Browns should 'stick with Manziel' at QB over injured starter McCown
thread.title_full: National Writer: Browns should 'stick with Manziel' at QB over injured starter McCown | Dallas Morning News

author: Brandon Wheeland
title: National Writer: Browns should 'stick with Manziel' at QB over injured starter McCown
text:
Johnny Manziel "showed enough glimpses of the athleticism and resourcefulness that made him a first-round pick" that it is time for the Cleveland Browns "to stick with Manziel" as their starting quarterback writes Nancy Armour of USA Today.
In a 28-14 victory against the Tennessee Titans last week, the former A&M QB posted a 133.9 quarterback rating on the way to his first career victory as a starter.
Though the 133.9 mark was good for the highest total from a Browns QB since 2007, Armour notes that the 2012 Heisman Trophy manager threw just four second half passes and was also strip-sacked twice for the second straight week.
Manziel has handled QB duties since starter Josh McCown went down with a concussion in Week 1. Though he has yet to clear concussion protocol, Browns writer Mary Kay Cabot shared via Twitter that the 36-year old signal caller was listed in front of Manziel on the unofficial depth chart.
#Browns unofficial depth chart, with Mccown listed as No. 1 and Manziel as No. 2 pic.twitter.com/ItDfWf2rNy
â€” Mary Kay Cabot (@MaryKayCabot) September 22, 2015 Against the Titans, "he was steadier in the pocket," writes Armour. "He showed more of the patience and savvy that it takes to be successful in the NFL, buying time until he spotted the open [WR Travis] Benjamin on the last touchdown rather than taking off running on the third-and-6 play."
If McCown can pass concussion protocol this week, which according to Cabot looks promising , head coach Mike Pettine may decide that the patience and savvy that Armour witnessed Manziel have on Sunday may be better served on the sideline rather than the field.
"While there's no guarantee Manziel would make it a regular scene as the starter," writes Armour, "Pettine and the Browns need to let him try.
